The chicken was so juicy and flavorful.  I wish the soup had been a bit colder so that I could have eaten it all, it was very good.  The potato was a bit dry and under salted but still pretty good.  It was also awesome to meet the knights after the show.  We got to talk to our knight and take a picture with him.  I can't wait to go back!!

What an awesosme time we had...front row.....woohoo..My son felt like a Prince since it was his birthday celebration. the food was outstanding, the staff excellent, the horses magnificent and the Knights were very entertaining...
Love everything about Midieval Times!! Excellent place to take the kids and watch a good show, so worth it. Best place to spend my 35th birthday. We'll be back for our anniversary, loved it.
This is such a fun place. They always put on an amazing show. The only downside is the price of tickets. Luckily they do have coupon codes most days that significantly drop the price.
Won tickets the other night from Facebook! Had an amazing night! The food was delicious and our waitress was wonderful.

Once in a lifetime is enough for this place. Very interesting experience. I wish I would have bought my own silverware as I had to pick apart my chicken and my children's chicken. Not sure how silverware is any more modern than the light up led wands they sell. Pretty pricy and could use some updating inside. 4 stars is only because my children and husband had and absolute blast.

Do not go to this place if you are a stiff person with no imagination or exotic new things. Was my first time going yesterday for my boyfriend's birthday and I can say it was definitely a great experience we both will remember forever. Can't wait to go back with friends to share the fun, also note you don't need to be a kid or have kids to enjoy this place.
When I went I had a great time!!  The food was actually good and the show was pretty fun!!  I would def go again anytime

Where do I even start. Went here for a friends birthday party, we brought 50+ people and we were hassled the ENTIRE night by the manager and his minions. We weren't allowed to cheer, we were "cheering too loud" for our Knights. We pretty much took up an entire section. The entire group was cut off from drinking and we were all kicked out had to wait in the cold for our bus. Trust me I know obnoxious annoying drunks but we were far from being belligerent. It's apparently a "family" show so don't go with your friends unless you plan on being silent. Also, show wasn't great. Kind of boring and bland. Maybe if it was more interesting people wouldn't have to conversate over the show. Food was mediocre not filling so don't turn to alcohol to help fill your tummy or you won't be there much longer.
So many years since I've been here.  I remember the experience was like non other. Very exciting and entertaining. The food was tasteless but it coordinated with the time theme.

I've been wanting to check this place out since 2001, and I finally went today with my husband and dad... It was a time well spent. 
At first I thought that even with the coupon, it's still expensive; however, after taking funny pictures in costumes,  eating a filling meal, and watching a fabulous show,  it's really not that expensive after all. Especially if you think about how much care they need to give to the horses and falcon. 
I would 100% recommend it, but it's definitely a once in a lifetime thing. No need to go several times.

Ye Olde Touristy Trappe

Some things never change.  And sometimes that's a good thing, because they were always cool from day one.  Point in case: Medieval Times.

Everyone knows what's in store for them when they buy tickets to this nationwide dinner theater chain.  Lots of fanfare, actors wearing costumes and talking in pseudo-old English accents, jousting, sword fights, utensil-less food, and wenches serving ale.  I hadn't been to a MT in over a decade, but I was glad to see that not much had changed.

The exterior facade is huge and built to look like a castle (obviously), and the inside is vast, consisting of the main arena and pre-show staging area, where you can spend outrageous amounts of money on tacky souvenirs.  Okay, not all of them are tacky and expensive--like the awesome stainless steel goblet I bought for only $10--but is buying a light up sword for $35 really worth your kid's happiness?  Can't answer, not a dad.....yet.

All of the actors stayed in character and did a commendable job rousing the crowd.  As a thespian myself, I can appreciate the effort the king & company put into their performances.  However, several of the knights seemed bored, and a couple looked downright unhappy.  The green knight was far and away the best, always smiling and nodding to our section when his horse trotted past.  Thankfully, he was the dude we got to cheer on!

The food was satisfactory.  A little on the anemic side, perhaps, but tasty enough.  Good garlic bread, TINY portion of soup, bland roasted potato wedges, tasty BBQ ribs, and a decent turkey/chicken leg (whatever, meat-on-a-stick).  The flaky pasty dessert--basically an apple turnover--was a nice way to cap off things.  Service was fine, but I had to laugh when the waitress/wench offered us more "Medieval Pepsi" or something equally silly (they couldn't just call it 'Cola of the Castle'?)  Booze prices were pretty inflated, so I passed.

The highlights were jousting and sword fights among the knights.  While there were a couple instances where the knights fell/jumped off their horses (to simulate getting 'knocked off' by the joust) and it looked phony, the majority of stage combat was actually very good.  When they clashed swords, sparks literally flew!  I also loved to see the knights using flails and shields as weapons.

Here's the TL;DR version--I had fun.  Yeah, it's pretty gimmicky and not particularly cheap, but it's just as enjoyable as I remember it as a wee lad.  I would happily return.

Protip: the Orlando, FL location has a working drawbridge and a moat!  Step up your game, Schaumburg MT!

Waiting for the show to start is smart on their side. Have the public waiting for the show while buying liquor and attraction items.

The food is good i expected mashed potatoes but it was decent.
The horse and knights are definitely worth checking out!!!

In no way authentic, but a blast none the less.

In fact the lack of authenticity may be what gives the experience it's charm.

Go for the show, the food is a convenient addition to the show price, and sit back and prepare to cheer at the jousting and sword battles and ooh and awe like a little kid at the gorgeously trained horses.

Meanwhile, you can giggle at: 
- Some of the HORRID fake accents (excluding the main guy and the king who thankfully don't sound like a freshman drama class)
- Being called My Lord / My Lady by people who voluntarily call themselves your wench
- Repeatedly adjusting your ridiculous paper crown
- Eating (with your hands) a meal composed of 25% ingredients available in medieval times / 75% not available until well after America was discovered (namely: potatoes, corn, tomatoes and garlic)

Revel in fruity drinks like the Dragon Slayer (mango slushie and coconut rum) and settle back for an awesome show.

I've been to medieval times many times.  Enjoyed it since I was young.  Rather than going to a restaurant and just eating, here you get to eat well and see a cool show!  I've been rather lucky my knight has won like 75% of the times I've attended!  The food is great, like seriously!  Last time I attended there wasn't a rib, in the past there was always and I enjoyed that.  But the 'normal' meal I've had here is garlic bread, tomato soup, potato, chicken, & rib (or something else now), and also a desert which is usually an apple pie type thing.  Plan to eat with your hands, because you don't get silverware!  I enjoy this, some people may not, but they do give you towels at the end of the meal also.  Overall, it's just a fun place to visit every now and then.  5 stars because I have had 0 problems and nothing to complain about.

 Some things to know:
1. Drinks are expensive.  Kind of like at a movie theater, the prices are very high for drinks, so plan on that, or plan on not drinking a lot.
2. There are deals!  Never pay full price for your tickets!  Check online and find a coupon code!
3. For children & families the earlier show times are best.  The later show times are best for a few buddies and drinking and yelling!
4. Don't bother paying extra for 'priority front row seating'.  I actually prefer sitting a couple rows back, and there are no bad seats in this place, all the seats are pretty much equal!

We took my mother there for her birthday this weekend,  our waiter Chris was great. The food was more than enough, hot, and delicious! 

Chris was very efficient and prompt with any additional request that we had. 

The show was different from the 1st time we went, longer even. 

My family and I had a great time!

This was the first time attending Medieval Times, and for me as a young adult, I really enjoyed it!  I got my ticket off of Groupon, so I only paid for dinner and tip for approximately $40 (which I hear is a much better deal than others had to pay).  I don't think I would have paid if it was more than $50.

The food was pretty decent.  I did not care for the tomato soup, but everything else was good.  I was worried about the fact that there was no utensils, but they gave out hand wipes.  Thank goodness!  I was filled with what was given to me.  I had garlic bread toast, soup, half a chicken (it seemed that big!), half of a potato, and some apple pastry.  

I enjoyed the show.  The knights fought, did some tournament things, etc etc.  I know the kids really enjoyed it, the ones next to us was really getting into it (they were SUPER upset that our team's knight lost... then they started to cheer for the bad guy.  My goodness).  I personally was worried that someone or one of the horses was going to get hurt, but nothing went wrong during the show.  I'm sure they have veterinary medical staff available for the animals, since they have so many horses.  

Overall a great experience for children. I wish women were able to be the knight though, that would have been great!

So much fun! 

I can't give it 5 stars because of the nagging feeling I have that the horses are subjected to abject cruelty...if not in the form of daily beatings, then at least by being forced to endure the canned earnestness of their ponytailed passengers, and their dramatic soliloquies and overall grandiosity. 

I bring this up because I swear that, during the evil knight's speech about his king destroying this kingdom, etc., his horse rolled his eyes like a million times.

The food was actually really tasty!

I liked being called m'lady.

Medieval Times makes for a fun date/outing/party/etc. if you're willing to fork out some cash. I will say, don't go frequently, the routine pretty much stays the same (I think it changes every 5 years or so), but it really is entertaining. Beautiful horses, men in tight pants, a stubborn falcon, finger food, the royal party, and all the things you can buy. 
    They say arrive early for various reasons (lines, getting seated, wanting you to buy stuff before the show, some routines done in the lobby, pictures), and upon arrival they do give the option to upgrade tickets. There are various levels of tickets, the basic package all the way to the several hundred dollar meet-the-king-get-knighted-fancy-cup-blah-blah-blah package. Check Groupon and elsewhere, you can often find some deals.
    The food is pretty good: some toasted bread, tomato bisque, a good portion of chicken, a sparerib, a potato, pepsi or ice tea, coffee, an apple turnover thing, and there is also a vegetarian option. Hopefully I didn't forget anything... it's eaten with your hands, btw, so don't look for utensils (hakuna matata, they give you wet naps). Our server was very nice, don't be a cheapskate with your tip, remember, they have to run around that arena with tubs of food for a whole row, they are probably paid like a server, which means not a lot so they rely on those tips.
    The show is fun. They have the different events and the horses really are beautiful. Have fun cheering for your team! They don't force you to participate but seriously, you're at Medieval Times, you've already lost some cool points showing up so lose a few more. The falcon was neat, as well. He was stubborn for awhile and wouldn't come down from his perch, I of course was on his side. The announcer for the evening was fantastic, love his voice, perfect for the role. 
    If you want an interesting insight on Medieval Times, Google the Reddit thread of Q's and A's by an old employee, it's pretty neat! There are other locations around the country, but this one is right off of the I-90 and Roselle Rd exit in Schaumburg.

Do you enjoy being squeezed in to a seat so small that the stranger next to you elbows you a dozen times? Do you enjoy keeping your bag between your feet because if you hang it off your chair the rude waitstaff will trip over it and dump Pepsi down your collar, then get mad at you? Do you enjoy bland, watery, luke warm tomato soup served in a ladle? Do you enjoy eating a dry, salty, half a chicken, with your hands, to the smell of horse shit? Do you enjoy eating half a salty shriveled potato, and a chewy, rubbery half an ear of corn? Do you enjoy a crap, predictable, floor show with the stage combat expertise of a middle school production of Camelot? Do you want to pay $50 each for the right to experience this all while wearing a paper crown? Then enjoy MEDIEVAL TIMES!

I had a family emergency in the middle of the show that made me step out for a second, where I inadvertently wandered into an employee area taking a phone call. This military looking dude, who I later found out was the general manager, Kevin Gadberry, literally starts yelling at me saying, 'Do you work here?!' (he obviously knew I didn't) then VIOLENTLY told me to 'GTFOH' as he stood an inch from my face. WTF??? Why would he treat a paying customer, who obviously made an honest mistake, so threateningly?? Ruined a night out with my family. 1 star for the rest of the staff being generally enthusiastic, a cool show, and decent food. But I can't help but think if I was a middle aged white guy like Kevin Gadberry is, would he have treated me differently? Smh go at your own risk PoC.

This weekend I went to Medieval Times for my 5th time....but 1st time with kids! I gotta say the whole experience takes on a whole new vibe when tiny people are involved & no liquor is present. My nieces had an awesome time and the experience was well worth it - but it's a one time thing. You won't catch me taking the little ones back there and the main reason is how things add up.

The wait to get in was very confusing & pretty horrendous. I wasn't sure what line I was supposed to be in so we picked a random line. It was a mighty long wait to get in. We arrived at the recommended time of 630pm for the 730pm show & ended up waiting about 30 minutes in various lines until we got into the actual castle's main hall. We had pre-printed our tickets so we bypassed a huge lineup of humans waiting to buy.

After we got inside, my nieces asked me, so what do we do now!? haha Poor little girls don't understand all the waiting involved at the castle. The whole thing reminded me of waiting at Disney World except if you're a good planner, you can get away with no waiting at Disney. Sadly at Medieval Times, there's no avoiding all the crazy lines & waiting around. 

We went up to the gift area and looked over their offerings. I'm the cool, fun Aunt so was planning on letting them each get a light up, flashy thing. One girl picked a sound making light up wand & the other picked the sword that lit up in three places. Fancy! $38 fancy. Also, for all purchases at Medieval Times you have to show your ID (apparently a new policy) and I didn't have mine on me. Thankfully I had a couple of 20 spots so I could fork over the cash. So...

Pro-Tip: Bring Cash for souvenirs and tips. It just makes life easier here.

The show itself was quite entertaining, well most of it. We sat in the Black & White section at the very end and the little ones complained about not being able to see well. They couldn't see the King & Princess at all and had a hard time seeing all the action. The beginning of the show was a bit confusing to them but they loved seeing the horses though all I could think about was how I hope they are treated well when not performing. The main actor/narrator guy is absolutely the star of the show and so fantastic! Great accent, on point facial expressions, he really gets into it and just is perfect in the role. The real action of the show comes in when the protective net comes down and the knights start battling. On guard!!! 

My nieces loved the show save for some complaints about viewing things. They also said a lot of the loud noises during the battle got a little scary (huge spiked balls banging against shields & a man snapping a whip, in particular). So if you have children scared of fireworks and things of that nature, this may not be the show for them.

Our waitress was very attentive and my nieces loved being called 'lady' and 'princess'. I caught her making a few little side comments which made me laugh and were more adult intended. I went with the vegetarian option for dinner which included a starter of hummus, pita bread, celery & carrots - pretty standard fare but the pita bread was warm and delicious. The main course had changed since the last time I went - a stew served in a metal pot of rice, veggies and what seemed to be beans, with a little packet of hot sauce on the side. It was a decent meal but any time the word 'decent' is used to describe something, it means it left something to be desired. After seeing my nieces' plates full of chicken, BBQ, potatoes and tomato soup, I will definitely be getting the normal meat eaters' meal on my next visit. The pastry was served hot & flaky with a warm apple center. I quite liked it and found it to be completely sufficient for dessert.

While having dessert, they came around to show us our picture we took with the Princess when we entered the castle. It was just SO cute, I couldn't resist forking the money over for it. $20 for 1 or $30 for 2. They must just bank on these expensive photos. I paid the $20 so my nieces could have a nice little memory of the three of us there and they appreciated it.

Tipping is the most confusing thing at Medieval Times. Yes, you need to tip. How much is the question? 20% of the tix price would be ridic. I paid $20 not knowing what was right. I've read people tip nothing to $2-$6 pp so in the future I will stick with just $5 or 6 pp. It's also a bit awkward outright telling your server how much tip you are giving them if you charge it.

So is Medieval Times fun? Heck yes it is!
But do they try to gouge every last cent from their guests? Heck yes they do.
$20 for the photo, $38 for a sword & a scepter, $20 tip and the tickets themselves cost $115, with a coupon code mind you.
Of course if you were to get drinks or anything else, that would just add more to the costs. 

$193 for 2 hours of fun makes it a once every 5 years type of activity!

There are few things I enjoy more than seeing a guy impaled on my lunch break. I am but a simple man. 

Once a month my coworkers and I do lunch at a local restaurant and rotate who gets to pick the place. For their picks we did Seafood, Mexican and Italian... and then came my turn. FINALLY. And guess where I chose? Yep... f*ckin' Medieval Times, man. #1 Coworker (that's what I call myself), strikes again! 

So, it was no cheap-feat coming here, as anyone who glances their prices can see, but they usually (always) have some sort of coupon or discount or buy-one-get-one going one to help soften the blow, though it's still priced a bit extravagantly for my general tastes, but I figured that I'd waited a year and half to be able to pick the lunch spot, I might as well make it an epic one because chances are I'll never get to pick again. 

We booked tickets for the Friday afternoon show, which is a bit shorter than their regular show and considered an 'educational show', which we learned as we pulled in and our three cars made up half the number of automobiles occupying the parking lot that weren't school buses. 

Inside the castle was madness incarnate. You had to work your way through a veritable moat of children to get through to the arena, but that didn't look like much fun so we ducked out to the bar and got a round of surprisingly reasonable drinks that come with souvenir holograph cups. Score! Plus, the bar wench loved us for being the only people there to order alcohol at 10:30 in the morning... also  probably the only people there who were old enough to order alcohol... besides the King, that is. Obvi. 

The educational show was just that, I guess. But I'm not really the best judge 'cause I was kinda totally buzzin' off my Mai Tai... until the garlic bread (which was actually really good) soaked it all up. I got a vegetarian meal, which for lunch meant I got a cold pasta salad and a fruit cup (served with a plastic fork - boo ya!) and the regular potato and corn on the cob side with a chocolate chip cookie happy ending. I actually didn't think the food was bad. I mean, I never would've ordered cold, pasta primavera and fruit for a meal if it weren't the absolute only option for veggies, but it was and it was fine. The show was holding my attention anyway. 

We were lucky enough to be amongst the green knight's section (aka- the BEST section) and we kicked the red knight's ass like none other, practically split him in half with his Medieval weaponry. Red home-dude didn't stand a chance... especially after our guy got his hands on the stick thingy with the chain and the silver balls that look a whole heck of a lot like truck-nuts hanging off them. 

The show had it's ups and downs. There was one part where guy comes out on a horses and they basically just prance for like 8 minutes to a song that sounded a lot like the one that plays in Home Alone when it's the montage of Kevin prepping his house with booby traps for the burglars. The song was great, the prancing lost it's luster around the 3-minute mark. 

It's not like a mind-blowing culinary experience, but it beats a $13 popcorn at $20+ movie tickets as far as entertainment, and now that I know how reasonable the mixed drinks are, well, game on!

Joust do it!

*Other highlight: The falcon took a crap right on the King's throne as he was flying by. Yay, poop!*

Food: 5 
I hate when trendy restaurants are too cool for condiments, but I definitely get it after eating here. Their menu is not huge, but when you do what they do as well as they do it you don't really need to offer much of a variety. Slow roasted and succulent, they have the type of dragon leg that you can just tell the chef de cuisine puts his heart and soul into each and every night. Sides include a perfectly seasoned potato, phenomenal garlic bread, and corn on the cob that literally melts in your mouth. (once you get it off the cob) Culinarily my dining companions and I were more than pleased with this foodie haven.

Service:3
Unfortunately they lose 2 stars here. :-( Our server was very pleasant and seemed to know the menu like the back of his hand, but sadly was somewhat hard to flag down. He did have quite a few other tables though so i guess its understandable when a popular place gets as busy as they were on our visit.

Ambiance:2 
Retro. Very retro. Seriously, the 1800s called and they want their everything back. Not really sure where they were going with this decor, but if the scents coming from the kitchen weren't as tantalizing as they were I may have lost my appetite.

Overall: 3 1/2
I'd definitely come back. Even though there are a few aspects I'm not totally thrilled about the place is great for groups and you know it's authentic cause absolutely every staff member spoke with an accent.

I hadn't been to Medieval Times since 6th grade ( over 15 years ago) & I remember having such an awesome time with my classmates. Years passed and I've always wanted to go back. I wondered if it would still be as fun as I remembered & if the food was any good. I would go on the Medieval Times website from time to time and check out the prices and feel a strong sense of nostalgia as I would browse the photos yelp.  The prices seemed ridiculously high to me ($228.96 for two adults and 2 children ages 5 & 7) so I never felt it was worth it. Then it happened. Easter 2015 was two days away and I had no plans. We usually have Easter celebrations at our home with egg hunts, basket swapping and lots of food ,drinks and family. This year I wanted to avoid the whole cooking, cleaning and being the host & wanted to do something just my hubby, kids & I. So I Googled Medieval Times coupons and tried the first one I saw which was buy one ticket get one free! It went through and my total was $149 for 4 tickets on Easter Sunday. I was so excited and thrilled that I was going to share this experience with my kids but silently  hoped that after 15 years the show hadn't gotten shitty. So Eater morning the boys have no idea that they are going to the castle. After they found their baskets and had breakfast we all got showered and ready. Every time the boys asked where we were going, we repeatedly told them we were going to  "have a jousting-ly good time." They were pretty annoyed. Then they seen the castle and they were like " MOM! DAD! Look a castle!!" My husband and I exchanged smiles  as we pulled in the parking lot and the boys realized this IS where we were going. We bought our tickets online so we passed the line of people who didn't and walked right into the waiting area. As mentioned in all the other reviews there are a lot of souvenirs you can buy along with booze. My husband & each asked the bartender what the strongest drink was and she said the Royal Knight which was very good and we got to keep the souvenir cup it came in. $14 for the first round and then refills are $8. We bought the kids each a light up sword for $24 each (ouch) and the yellow flag to cheer on our yellow knight was $2. We arrived about 45 minutes early and the wait for the show to start did not even feel that long. I suggest coming as early as possible if you want decent seats. Once seated at our table our "wench" came along and offered drinks and talked a little about the food we were to be served. Her service was just OK. A different wench that's exclusively for alcohol came along and asked if we wanted to order another cocktail. We  asked her the same question we asked the bartender when we first arrived, " what is your strongest drink"? She stated the long island was the strongest and best so we ordered it. Big mistake do not order it! It tasted like a cup of lemonade, way too much sweet and sour! My husband even left his seat during the show to exchange our drinks for the royal knight drink and we stuck with that the remainder of the night. There was a lot of food and my husband was surprised that it was actually very good. They no longer serve the rib and now serve buttered corn in its place. While I thought the show itself could have been better, I was pretty content with how happy my kids were, how good the food was and my cocktail lol. When we left my children said it was the best Easter ever. So there ya go. Best Easter ever for kids

You always see the castle when you drive down I-90 west and you wonder what all the rave is about.  If you've never been there I suggest getting a small or large group and make an event out of it.  Instead of doing the same boring thing like going to a bar, stop into medieval times!  The food was not that bad, chicken leg, garlic bread and soup, apple turnover and a rib.  It was not that bad at all.  If you're a vegetarian no worries they have soup and veggies for you plus I believe some hummus. I posted a picture of all the food.  The tickets were pretty cheap but I ended up spending over $100 on drinks!  My friends and I had a blast! You don't go there for the food or drinks, go for the experience.  It's not like I'm going to be planning an event to come here every year but once maybe every 5 to 6 years seems ideal!

We took our 2 grandkids for our grandson's 6th birthday and it was a great time.    They LOVED it and we did too actually.   The food was really good, surprising since there are so many people, but very tasty.     We got there as the doors opened, so we got great seats.   Our knight didn't win, but we loved him anyway since he threw a carnation to our grand daughter!The staff was amazing and very helpful.    It is a great place to go and a great show

I've been here twice this summer, so I saw the same show twice, although they do periodically change it. I'm an adult and I have only ever come here with adults, and I still have a good time. The trip into the dungeon is worth it - it's like $2 or something. And as long as you can restrain yourself from buying tons of souvenirs, the price is good overall. The only time I ever paid full ticket price was part of a birthday package. But, please, don't ever pay the full price for tickets. You can buy them discounted everywhere- Groupon, Craigslist, all over. 
The food is alright, and one thing I have to really commend this place for is their ability to accomodate food allergies. One of my friends can't eat at most restaurants because they cook everything on the same stoves, cross-contaminate utensils and countertops, etc. My friend can actually eat here without getting sick, which is probably why he keeps having parties here. You can also get vegetarian (not sure about vegan) options. 
If you have a couple drinks at the bar before the show, you'll probably leave feeling pretty full and satisfied. The extra cake and virgin daiquiri you get in the birthday package is almost too much. 

I swear, the black and white knight always loses, though, what's up with that?

Good Clean Fun!  Food was good and the show was very entertaining.  Fun for kids and adults alike.  Can be pricey if you don't buy online with a retail me not coupon.  With the discount 40 bucks a head is an awesome price for dinner and a show.  I went with a group of 10 for an adult birthday party, but will return again to take my son.

great experience!!!
We were a bit late so we our seat at row 24 but our section had no one on their first row so we got upgraded!!! our server was so nice and helpful and made sure we were taken care of.  I wish I remembered his name.The food was really good and flavorful. I had a pina colada, that was kinda blah, too sweet for me. The castle itself is amazing and the show was very thought out. we really enjoyed it.  even My mom who doesn't speak english knew who she was cheering for.  Definitely look forward to coming back.

So I took advantage of a coupon that I received and thought I would check this place out. I probably would agree with some other Yelpers that I would not have paid full price.

I must say, I was pleasantly surprised. It was a fun and different experience that my whole family enjoyed. 

The food was good, better than I expected actually. I didn't like the no utensil rule, so I asked the waitress if she could bring some to us. Luckily, they have some plastic flatware for people who need it.

I don't think there's a need to do this more than once, though!

My wife and I are huge fans of renaissance faires, and we go to Medieval Times to give us our fantasy fix during the winter months. I've been going to Medieval Times for nearly twenty years, and have always had a great time as both a kid and as an adult. 

If you wait for a promotion (which happens pretty often), the experience is pretty reasonably priced. Last year my wife and I took advantage of the Valentines Day deal, which gave us each a glass of wine, a framed photo, dungeon tour, and a bunch of knick-knacks for $99, in addition to the full meal and show. Just keep checking their website and Facebook, and you'll eventually come across a great deal. 

The castle itself is well decorated and fun to explore. The staff is all dressed up and in character. Everyone who works there has been pleasant and helpful in my experience. 

The food is surprisingly excellent! I'm a vegetarian, and was quite happy with my hummus/veggie plate and 5-bean stew. I remember the chicken being tasty as well, during my meat eating days. Our waiters have always been friendly, quick and accommodating. 

The tournament itself is pretty spectacular. The actors are obviously very well trained, and put on an impressive performance of horsemanship and stage combat. A different house wins each time, and I always find myself grinning and laughing as I cheer on my favorite knight as he battles "to the death". 

I recommend Medieval Times to anyone. It's a great time all around that you'll remember for years to come!

Two of my grad school colleagues just finished some major exams and wanted to celebrate by going to Medieval Times.

To be honest, it was kind of crappy:

Pros:
- The whole place seemed fairly well-run.  It was clean, things started on time, and servers were courteous and professional.

- Having read the reviews I expected that the food would be awful.  It really wasn't.  The chicken was actually pretty good and the portions were certainly ample.  The Texas Toast, though, was worse than the frozen stuff I can get in the supermarket and the hilarious single rib was fatty and bland.

Cons:
- The show was nothing to write home about.  Over the course of nearly two hours, I didn't see a single thing that made me say, "Wow!  How'd he do that?"  I would say that the knights are competent at best.  They can ride horses.  They can do some reasonably passable choreographed sword fighting.  But they don't really do any stunts and I don't see how they could with the size of the arena.  

Maybe the falconry exhibition would have been cool if the falcon hadn't decided to perch up in the ceiling for a minute or two while the king awkwardly ad-libbed.  Actually, that was kind of funny.

- As everyone has mentioned, the tips should be included in the price of admission.  The way they're doing it now is obnoxious.

- I'm pretty sure they threw in a completely random and unexplained $8 "processing fee" when I reserved the tickets on their website.  

- Drinks were weak (although not quite as ridiculously expensive as I expected).  

- There is absolutely no reason to show up anywhere close to an hour early.  We walked in five minutes before the start time and we were fine.

Miscellaneous
- There's one thing I don't really get about this operation.  As far as I can tell, this show is really aimed at a seven or eight year-old.  But then it really gets quite violent at the very end, which is sort of jarring. They also don't seem to have a kid's meal option.  What little kid needs half a chicken, a rib, a bowl of soup, bread, and dessert?  It's really kind of weird.

Omg what a disappointment. My wife was asking me for years to go I finally gave in. My instinct was right. First off we waited 45 min in a crowd so tight we couldn't turn around while they gave their stupid speech and then tried to call in certain people by colors even though we couldn't move. It was beyond stupid from there it only got worse. Bad food horrible show the Knights looked like 98lb girls was embarrassing. I'm ashamed I was even there. Do not waste your money on this disaster. I would rather sit in court for two hours than sit through that again. They should change the name from medieval times to mediocre times. I've had more fun getting a tooth pulled than that joke. Fire everyone and close. You owe me 2 hours of my life back

Sadly enough, i live 15 minutes away from medieval times and last week was my first time EVER going (keep in mind that i'm 23)
My boyfriend found a groupon, so we went and we werent expecting the food to be great because his dad kinda put in our heads that it wasnt anything special.
On the contrary, the food was good! better than what we were expecting, on the plus side, YOU EAT WITH YOUR HANDS, awesome.

What i liked
- eat with your hands duh
-you get to keep the cups you get with your alcoholic drinks.
-horses are awesome
-all the knights have long hair
- everyone speaks like they're from Asgard (Thor, come on people)

What I didnt like
-Sitting front row, squished between people. the lady next to me spilled her beer on me :-(

overall, its really cool, definitely something you should experience especially since there aren't that many medieval times in the country.
A good thing to bring your kids to!

The kids loved Medieval Times.  The food was slightly above average, the kids loved having the opportunity to eat with their hands and not get yelled at by mom and dad.  The entertainment is very good, although very clearly choreographed and staged.  Don't get me wrong, I think the performers do put a lot of effort into it and I think the choreography is how they keep it safe for them, I just think they could do a little better job not making it so obvious.

Now the price was pretty high and they do seize every opportunity to extract more money out of you (drinks, souvenirs, upgrades, etc.)

I think the key is to show up pretty early to get a good seat.  If you're going on a weeknight it appears there aren't a ton of people visiting so you can get very good seats without paying for the upgrade packages.

It was one of those great experiences for the kids. I expect it was a once in a lifetime experiences and probably not something will be coming back to any time in the future, but that's purely from the standpoint of once you've seen the show you've really seen it all.

Highly recommended for a reasonably good meal, a very good show and overall a highly entertaining evening!

JOUST ON! 

Dost thou knowest the time?  "MEDIEVAL TIMES: DINNER AND TOURNAMENT" time! Let us go tither!

I was following my social media & saw the venue had awesome Medieval Times, "Joust for the Cause" t-shirts. I have been through full surgery twice in April to remove a breast mass, so I emailed the "contact us" via website about where to buy/get a t-shirt being a huge supporter of October as Breast Cancer Awareness month. I certainly "Go Pink" & support "Fight for the Cure" everything the very best I can. I was emailed back saying, they would love to ship me a T-Shirt free of charge & to please confirm my mailing address. (I must have been on file from multiple prior visits over the years or for being signed up on their email lists.) A couple weeks had passed & I was still waiting at months end. I replied to the email if they ever shipped 1 since it didn't make it to me yet, but if available or lost in mail I was still interested. I was kindly replied to that they were sorry for the delay (They were sorry? It is my pleasure to have received your gift, kindness, and modesty in that way!) but were trying to find me a size small & weren't having much luck nearing month end (my guess would be contacting the sales coordinators at the other castles). This was beyond thoughtful effort & my gift arrival was exceedingly generous beyond expectations. This is all a gift, so any good person shall be grateful for ANY size shirt delivery at any time. I was THRILLED that my email led to a package on my doorstep, the when opened included: A t-shirt, a pink Medieval Times goblet of fantastic quality - metal, durable, the splendid ones you see on the Castle's bar for sale & the most heart touching part was an envelope enclosed w/ a letter. The unfolded letter read, "Our Kingdom is in need of a Fearless Warrior & Survivor Just like YOU! Enclosed you will find two free tickets redeemable at the Chicago Castle." The envelope had a post it stuck to it reading, "Hi Amanda! Feel free to call me directly @ ###-#### to book your reservation. -Nereide Crisologo; Sales Coordinator." WOW. Talk about a company, sales coordinator, or INDIVIDUAL person going above & beyond. I am tremendously thankful for everything, including people like you. The company is blessed to have you on their staff, & customers are hugely lucky. I am happy just crossing paths w/ people like you! Godspeed!

I called to book my tickets & chose the cheapest day I have seen all year: Black Friday. $30 for ALL seats. We were granted the best seats I could ever imagine, front row of the mid blue section. I had a friend from Germany (working on an internship for his PhD in USA for 3 months) visiting & wanted to show him OUR castle. Germany has real castles, but we have the BEST castles with the whole set-up that makes the entire evening at Medieval Times so grand. We pulled in the free parking lot and he giggled & said, "That's a castle? That is very cute!" Follow-up after visit, he was DELIGHTED by everything inside; Staff, Museum, Bar, Feast, Knights, Real Horses, Attire, & SHOW! Neddy & Medieval Times - I cannot thank you enough in words. You have been a Godsend through a very long tough year. What you have done for me, & the friend I was able to share it with, was nothing less than amazing. I have always loved Medieval Times, but now will forever be a loyal fan of your business from the bottom of my heart. To reach out like that to one person is remarkable. In life, we can't do everything, but we can do something. I have reached for a hand, & you reached back to my HEART. Godspeed to you! Neddy: Thanks-thou art most kind my fair lady!

The castle is most beauteous. Arrive early & see the Medieval Torture Museum. It's a small walk through that is painfully fascinating! The bar makes excellent drinks & even the normal cups are plastic holographic keepsakes. Mayhap I will fetch the ale. Yay, methinks so! I had 2 pina coladas He had 2 beers.

Dinner is served 1 item at a time during the show. The Feast: Garlic Bread, Tomato Bisque Soup, Oven-Roasted Chicken (Dragon Leg per the Royal King), Spare Rib, Herb-Basted Potato, Pastry, Coffee. Beverages included (unlimited refills) are: Pepsi, Diet, Iced Tea, Lemonade. A vegetarian feast is available & I hear they are served silverware. Silverware? Nay, methinks not during this era! Methinks thine art cheaters!

Ye cheer for a knight of thy color section through the games followed by mounted & ground combat. The noble knights ride out like strapping Lords atop majestic horses. Our blue knight was grand! Ye art quite handsome. I have been admiring thee. Ye did well in the games & combat. HUZZAH! Tis most splendid! After the show, you can meet your knight for a photo. I asked if I could sit on his lap or chair edge. He said, "Certainly." Greetings, Blue Knight! How fare thee? Perchance we shall meet again. Fare thee well, My Lord!

Medieval Times- Cheers for an "out-of-the-ballpark" evening & spectacular customer service!

If Chuck E. Cheeses and Game of Thrones had a baby, it would be Medieval Times. Special note, Medieval Times is not a good idea for those with equinophobia (fear of horses).

After all of these years and a recession, it's amazing that Medieval Times is still in business. Surprisingly, I really enjoyed myself. For starters, they had beer and not just your typical Miller products but Newcastle Brown Ale. $6 for a 16 ounce beer - not bad when you're used to downtown prices. The price doesn't bother you as much after being called "m'lord" from the bartenders. 

All of the knights had long flowing manes with facial hair - I wouldn't be surprised if they were previous Metallica cover band members. The entertainment was a medieval version of WWE style action and choreography. Just like professional wrestling, you think it's stupid in the beginning until you get sucked in and can't help but cheer along. The actors did a great job of keeping in character. In particular, the announcer had an excellent Old English accent - definitely better than Tyrion Lannister's. But like Game of Thrones, there was a lot of dialogue and I didn't understand the plot but kept watching anyways. 

There is something about Medieval Times that brings out the child in you. Maybe it's something about girls and horses and boys and swords. For horse lovers, the horses are definitely an attraction since you'll see horse choreography at its best - expect plenty of galloping and prancing. For the boys, you'll see plenty of clashing of weapons from maces, long swords, to battle axes. If you want to add to your collection or take a special souvenir home, you can even buy real swords. You can get a claymore or a rapier to add your chainmail set. Purchase $200 worth of value, you'll get 50% off a shield - perfect for the LARPer in your family. 

For the overall value, we got a deal for buy one get one free so it ended up being $35 a person. Not bad when you think about it in terms of a two hour show with dinner. Otherwise, I would not recommend going for the full price of $59.95 for adults. It's equivalent to watching a movie and going out to eat for dinner but for the whole family.

In the end, Medieval Times is really for the children. For parents, here is a breakdown of why Medieval Times is great for your child's next party:

1. Children are well behaved and seated which makes large groups easy to manage
2. There are horses and plenty of them
3. Two hours of entertainment that also comes with a full meal
4. Your children will become the coolest kids in school afterwards

Ok so the prospect of talking in a strange medieval dialect while bravehearting my food (hands only) didn't strike me as being an awesome evening.  

Man was I wrong!!!!

This was our first visit, went for hubbies bday and it was one of the coldest nights this winter---thought we were going to be the only people there--but luckily some other cray cray people wanted to come out for an evening of entertainment---and lovely liquid libations to warm them up.

It is a little on the pricey side if you pay full price but they were running a promo where all tix were $35, kiddies $29--tolerable---they are great at upselling a variety of packages.  Actually I would say they're pretty good at the upselling game.  The show started at 7:30 but they encourage you to be there at 6:30---so you can be bombarded by all the randomness from the wine bar, main bar, glitter tattoos, things that light up/glow, torture museum---I give them props---they're just trying to get that paper! We opted for the "Royal" upgrade $10 more--includes VIP seating, program, banner to waive, behind the scenes DVD.

In terms of the drinks at the bar--thought I was going to pay and arm and a leg, but the prices were actually pretty decent and about the same as going to any other restaurant bar.  Lots of yummy concoctions in fanciful cups.  Kiddies had their non alcoholic slushies in the knight head cups--and they were happy.  Food was actually a lot better than I expected it to be--bonus!--not the best since its food for the masses--but could have been a whole lot worse.

The upgrade was totally worth it for us---we actually got upgraded to the front row----so my group was giddy, tipsy, and feeling good with a touch of brute excitement.  Luckily we were seated in the area of the winning knight so we had a blast cheering him on.  The show actually had a nice variety and it wasn't just a bunch of jousting dudes with long hair on pretty horses.

Staff was attentive and all were really nice.  My youngest was given a "token" (sash that said queen of the tournament) from the winning knight....so she was excited.  We did a lot of screaming, yelling, eating, and drinking!  It was a great knight!!! (wink wink)
I enjoy coming here every few years. It hasnt changed much time to time but still overall an enjoyable experience. The food is good, the jokes corny, and the crowd is pretty energetic.

Medieval Times is great and could be a lot of fun.  When my son was little, this was one of his favorite places.  We have gone so many times now...and it is always exactly the same show...maybe it is time they switch it up a bit?

We got one Spicy Noodle bowl, spring rolls, and a DIY bowl with chicken, squash, pickled veggies, and rice. I also got the spicy curry sauce on the side, and...WOW.

My DIY bowl was amazing! As a resident of the Bay area, this place immediately evoked Asian Box for me. I have to say, while the concept is identical, ShopHouse tasted much better. I was not expecting that. Nice surprise!

I am stingy with 5 stars and give them only when they're truly deserved, and ShopHouse takes the cake in this style of food. (I can also confidently give this rating as my friends and family have been coming since it opened and raving about it to me over the phone.) 

What I'm angry about, but not enough to ding them for star-wise, is that they are making my list of "Restaurants I Wish I Could Take to California" grow longer. C'mon!!

I have been to the downtown Chicago location a few times and after trying this one, I have say, I like this one more!  Every component of the meal was better executed in Schaumburg.

I am not exactly thrilled that this once gluten-free establishment recently added wheat products to the menu, but I am still so happy that they have so many gluten-free vegetarian options.

I highly recommend the tofu, even if you are a meat eater... it is really good!  I love the texture and the flavors.

And for sauces: I like to mix the tamarind with the peanut sauce, or if I want a bit of a spicy kick, I ask for both the sweet chili and peanut sauce.

Sadly, as of Nov 11th, I heard Chipotle is planning to shut er down, so I had to check this place out.

I wish I came here earlier -- the concept is pretty much fast-casual, where you pick your base (noodles or rice) and your proteins and toppings. I like places like this because they have a really good nutrition calculator online so if you're health-conscious like me, you can always look up what you're getting. I got the Pork & Chicken Meatballs with thai chilli sauce. It was absolutely phenomenal. The staff there were super nice and explained everything, considering it was my first time there.

Sad to see this place go, it's definitely better than your Panda Express.

Everyone be try'na CURRY favor with me.

A pair of freebie lunch cards were burning a hole in my wallet, so I had no qualms about cashing these in on the last Sunday in July.

For the longest time, I always thought of these guys as the "Asian Chipotle".  So it made all too much sense when I learned that ShopHouse's parent company is, in fact, Chipotle.  The build-your-own food format is the same, the look and feel of the restaurant's interior is similar, even the friendly staff are on-par with those at the Mexican variant.

The vouchers -- from an Elite event back in mid-February, hey hey! -- were good for a free bowl of whatever.  So we worked our way down the line and built our entr√©es as we saw fit.  Neither LeAnn P nor myself found the chilled rice noodles to be an appealing 'base', so she got brown rice instead.

I went with the steak laab, which wasn't a great choice, as I wound up eating literally everything except the meat, which was coated with something unexplainable and crunchy (toasted rice?)  Meat shouldn't be crunchy.  Like ever.  Maybe next time I'll remember my mistake and opt for the meatballs instead.

All the others toppings and accoutrements were great; even the red curry tasted fine with the roasted green beans and pickled vegetables.  LP enjoyed her selection more than I did mine.  Their mango-coconut mini dessert was just as adorable (and tasty!) as I remember from a previous visit.

I was more than a little bummed that their beer on tap (Daisy Cutter, a personal favorite) couldn't be served to me, because no employee working there was over 21!  State laws are all fine and good, but when daddy can't get his 3pm drink on, sh*t doesn't bode well.

Fortunately, we got comped not only a bottled ginger ale and a fountain beverage, but ALSO one of the mango-coconut rice parfaits for the inconvenience of being denied alcohol.  That was nice of them (and frankly, the act of generosity saved their butts a star).

Bread = 3.5
Circuses = 4

Their wall of Sriracha is a saucy sight to behold (teehee), and the dining area was kept clean of any garbage.  Employees were chill.

Recommend?  Sure.

But I wasn't exactly BOWLed over.

Delicious! I'd heard of this southeast Asian concept chipotle a few years ago when it was in the works. Didn't realize that there was one so close to me - finally got to try it today! 

It was a nice change in flavor - I made my own bowl and got half meatballs/half chicken over brown rice, with green beans, red curry, crispy garlic and herbs.   The curry was definitely fairly spicy. My friend got the shophouse bowl which had green curry - also delicious. We tried the spring rolls which were pretty good as well.

Obviously not "authentic" southeast Asian food, because you kind of get to create your own thing but with ingredients that could be found in SEA food. That being said, nobody calls Chipotle "authentic" Mexican food so why should this be any different? Who cares, it tastes good!

First thing I did upon returning to Chicago in 08 Years was to visit all the food place we don't have in California. Asked my Ex-roommates whats the latest !!!

This place is like back in California.) .Have the option to fill your Bowl with Healthy Options..Salad, Rice, Brown Rice or Noodles to start with...then you add the meat, Vegetables, Sauce....

Kudos loved this place

A-OK Shophouse! Fast casual is always a win in my book and this place does a great job.

Service is fast, friendly, and helpful. ShopHouse is owned by Chipotle so their concept is similar. They offer a menu you can select from or you can create your own bowl. It's southeast Asian cuisine, which is new to me but it's pretty good.

My first go around I went with their spicy noodle bowl because I love spicy foods. I must warn you (just like I was warned), this spice is no joke! The flavor was great, but it was a heat where you either had to just keep eating or drink a lot on between bites! Honestly, too hot for me.

Second time around I got smart and decided to create my own bowl. That way if it was too spicy I only had myself to blame right? Right. Well I ended up avoiding the heat all together and went with a peanut sauce, but my combo was very good: jasmine rice, chicken, beef, pickled veggies, slaw, garlic, peanut and vinegar sauce.

I love that their meals come with a spring roll. If you're ever thinking about getting dessert, do! They offer a coconut parfait that is delicious.

Overall a good fast casual restaurant. Friendly service, reasonable prices, and a great location. It's to be noted that they offer beer as well. ShopHouse is nothing I'd go out of my way for, but if I'm in the area it's a nice quick food option.

ShopHouse was a fine, quick casual lunch. It wasn't remarkable, it wasn't subpar, it was just *fine.* 

The service was quick and friendly and I love me a fast casual restaurant. The space itself is on the smaller side but lends itself well in location and concept for plenty of hungry Schaumburgers (is that a word?) seeking a fast Asian inspired lunch. 

The options, just like its parent company Chipotle, are fairly limited. I choose with the peanut chicken rice bowl - I'm a sucker for peanut sauce anything. The bowl itself wasn't overly stuffed and while I definitely had enough food and more, don't expect gargantuan portions that you've witnessed at Chipotle. While the items in the bowl tasted pretty fresh, there wasn't much pizazz and the peanut sauce wasn't overly flavorful. 

Schaumburg has its fair share of both fast casual and fantastic Asian cuisine. While ShopHouse is a fine addition that broaches these too categories, there are plenty of fast casual and Asian eats that do a much better job on the flavor scale.

I probably wouldn't have gone out of my way to try ShopHouse, but I'd gotten a few freebies from a Chipotle-related promotion, so that expedited it on my "To Try" list.

In short: 
IMO the flavors are SUPER MILD (fyi, my threshold is "mild-to-moderate" heat).

If you want a dish with ANY spice, I suggest the Red Curry sauce, PLUS get the chilies on the side!

_____________________________________________

Bowl #1 w/Tamarind sauce:

chilled rice noodles, chicken satay, squash with Thai basil, green papaya/cucumber slaw, Tamarind sauce, and crispy garlic.

Verdict: 3/5

Holy minescule amount of chicken! The bowl was VERY noodle-heavy without enough chicken to balance it out.

The Tamarind sauce lent a very light, somewhat tangy flavor. I couldn't taste the garlic.

Spice? What spice???
NONE of the ingredients contributed even a minescule amount of heat.

The ONLY plus is that the bowl is so "light" that I ate the whole thing - before a pilates class, no less - without feeling like a glutton.
____________________________________________

Bowl #2 w/Green Curry sauce:

brown rice, steak, green beans, green curry sauce, pickled veggies, fresh chilies on the side (exceptttt they gave me this green stuff - not the pretty red chilies showcased in everyone else's pics..)

Verdict: 4/5

There was more meat this time, so the bowl was FAR more balanced than my first.  I liked the flavor of the steak - both that and the beans were lightly charred, but no "burnt" taste at all.  

Flavor-wise, it was fine, but had hardly ANY spice.  The green curry lent a VERY mild heat; anyone who likes even a remote amount of spice will want to add the chilies or Sriracha. I added the green chilies and it was soo much better!
_____________________________________________

Bowl #3 w/Red Curry sauce:

brown rice, steak, green beans, squash, red curry sauce, pickled veggies, and Herb salad, w/ green chilies on the side.

Verdict: 4/5

MUCH better flavor-wise! The heat was still on the milder side, so I'm thankful I asked for those chilies again! This was my most balanced and generous bowl ingredients-wise. 


Soooo, during this bowl creation, I asked for pickled veggies and the worker accidentally put on papaya slaw. No biggie: I asked if she could just remove the slaw from the top and replace with the vegs. She said "Ok," but the next thing I knew, she TOSSED the WHOLE BOWL in the GARBAGE and started a new one! WTH?! Apparently she was TOLD to THROW OUT THE ENTIRE BOWL!  Why?! If I had known before she pitched it, I would have just taken it. So wasteful!  Sheesh.
_____________________________________________

Service: 5/5
Each time I've visited, staff was friendly and smiley.


Other:
I'm a fan of their compostable containers. Make sure you transfer those leftovers to another container, though, because otherwise things get leaky.


Overall impression? 
Shophouse is the perfect example of a 3.5-star rating. It's a nice addition to healthier assembly-line fast food, but the scrimping on ingredients (and $1+ charges for additional veggies) will keep me heading back...

...to Chipotle.

When I heard that the brainchild of Chipotle wanted to do something similar with Asian food, I was excited. Fast, casual, and made to order? For $7 or $8 a bowl to boot?

It all sounds good on paper, but like the 2016 Chicago Bulls, it doesn't necessarily have the right chemistry. Shophouse says its food is influenced by SouthEast Asian cuisine, specifically Thai and Vietnamese.

I had the Shophouse Bowl, which had pork and chicken meatballs on top of jasmine rice covered in a green curry with roasted corn. The pickled vegetables (sliced carrots, radish) definitely come from the Vietnamese side while the curry is Thai. The meatballs were definitely a Chipotle Mexican Asian fusion.

While the mashup of ingredients tasted fine, I couldn't help but desire authentic Vietnamese or Thai. There just wasn't enough curry to cover the rice, and the meatballs were... well they were okay.

Warning for those that are sensitive to spicy dishes - Neely everything has a healthy amount of heat to it. I'm someone who can handle the spiciest kimchi chigae, so I'm no wimp.

Service was fast, friendly, and it seems all the lines have moved from Chipotle to Shophouse, at least during lunch.

Unfortunately, my stomach later regretted my choice of food. You can say that the empire struck back. Ugh. I think I'll hit up my local hole in the walls for the real deal and skip the regret my body felt from fusion confusion.

If you're not familiar with ShopHouse, just think of it as an Asian version of Chipotle. You get to pick what you want in a food assembly line like Chipotle but the food being offered are more Asian Fusion. It is a unique taste and very convenient for a quick food stop/lunch break. However, I am not a fan of the Americanized take to these Asian dishes. It is very healthy and I can tell that all the ingredients are made fresh, but it's just not like typical authentic Asian dishes that I am familiar with.

So you get to pick a base (white rice, brown rice, noodles, or salad); a type of meat (chicken, laab, pork & chicken meatballs, and tofu); vegetables (broccoli, corn, squash, & green beans); sauces (various curry sauces, peanut sauce, and tamarind sauce); and then garnishes. 

Overall, you can be very creative and add whatever your heart desires but if you're not sure what taste good with what, you can always play it safe and order a pre-made bowl. 

This location also serves beer and ginger ale sodas that are really yummy!

In conclusion, if you are looking for a quick food break and are craving Asian Fusion, this is the right place for you!

I wasn't really sure what to expect.  ShopHouse?  What does that mean?  Is it a restaurant or a store?  After checking out the website it is like a Chipolte but from Southeast Asian that has gluten free food.  Hurray.

The hubs and I had lunch here during the week.  The dining room is on the small side and you need to get really close to the people next to you if the place is packed.  Luckily there was enough room to have a one table buffer between us and the guy to our left.

The concept is common these days, stand in line, pick the options you want, pay, then sit and eat.  I got the chilled rice noodles, chicken satay, green beans, peanut sauce, pickled veggies, herb salad, green papaya salad, and thai hot sauce-bowl.  I also got an unsweetened ice tea and some spring rolls.  

The food was good.  I would say the flavors are a Thai-Vietnamese combo.  The price is pretty standard for fast service lunch places.  Two entrees, two soft drinks, side of spring rolls for $25.  I would come back here...maybe for a salad or rice bowl...further investigation is needed.

I was so thrilled when I learned that ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen would be opening in the Chicago area right before my vacation there. Immediately after landing our plan was to head over and give this Chipotle owned chain a try. What is great about this place was that it is actually 100% gluten free and dairy free! Perfect for me who has celiac disease and a dairy allergy, I can have literally everything on the menu! For our bases we got rice and salad. For the meat option I chose half meatballs and half tofu. For veggies I went with the squash and the broccoli and for the sauce knowing me I went with some of the spiciest and some of the vinaigrette. Then I finished off my bowl with all the topping options.

We ended up getting sodas and two of the mango rice dessert cups.
Now for what I liked, I really enjoyed the meatballs they had great flavor. The entire bowl was quite tasty and really flavorful. The mango rice dessert was very small but also just the perfect ending to our meal.

The problems I had were just basically one thing and that was how spicy the meal was. I wasn't expecting it to be so hot. What did it for my bowl I think was the Thai chiles on top which just made the entire bowl flaming. I had to have a full drink next to me the entire time.

Overall though I really did enjoy the bowl and am definitely hoping for one to show up in the San Francisco Bay Area. The employees were so friendly and willing to answer any questions I had. Everything was clean as well which is always a good thing to mention. Definitely give this place a try if you are in the area. Great for those of us with celiac disease, absolutely no chance of cross contamination.

When in Schaumburg I always stop here now. It is incredibly tasty and delicious. Don't skip dessert, Coconut Rice and Mango Parfait is perfect. Well done!
Also love the design of the place.

I wasn't a fan of Chipotle during my first visit. It wasn't until I found my combination of ingredients that I was addicted and I can see the same thing happening for others at ShopHouse.¬†

ShopHouse is part of the Chipotle chain that focuses on Southeast Asian (SEA) cuisine drawing influences from Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia. The setup is very similar to what you would find from the streets of Bangkok where you choose the type of ingredients and toppings all in one bowl.¬†For fans of SEA cuisine, you'll appreciate the amount of flavor and textures from the fresh ingredients and spice combinations for only $8.¬†The flavor profile might be too strong for some since there is a level of heat in most of the dishes.¬†Notable items on the menu: green beans (flavored with a chili jam), Vietnamese style meatballs, and Thai papaya salad. Find the combination that suits you best and the addiction will quickly catch on.

This would have been a five star experience if they allowed for double scoops like at Chipotle, had more vegetables to choose from, and had chopsticks. Despite what the cashier said, people in Thailand do use chopsticks specifically for noodle dishes. I would know since it's where my family is from.

Damnit. I've been asking Chipotle to bring ShopHouse to Chicago on social media for months. I feel partly responsible for bringing this disaster to us. Sorry guys. I love Asian food and I love Chipotle so I figured this would be a success. Not so much. The flavors aren't down pat. They aren't Asian.. They aren't even tasty Americanized Asian flavors. They're just meh and bland. Very bland. I highly enjoyed the pork and chicken spring rolls and if in the area, I might stop in for those.

I didn't enjoy the bowls though. I went for the Shophouse. I don't recommend it. First, it's not real curry. I've never had curry with not even a hint of coconut milk, until I tried ShopHouse. I don't think there's any coconut milk in it. The meatballs were so skimpy. I chopped them up so I had enough for my bowl, but I ended up still having half of the rice left after finishing the meatballs. In fact, I brought the leftover rice home and made chicken sausage and STILL had more left. If you adore rice, then this might be a good concept for you. I mean I like rice, but damn.  My husband got steak laab with rice and green curry. I liked his steak a lot and there was plenty of it in the bowl, but again the curry. BLAH. He also had the charred green beans, which I liked.

Also, why are you being so effing skimpy on the veggies? Most businesses will over-veggie you (I definitely understand skimping on the protein, but why are you skimping on the slaw?) They use tweezers to put certain things on your bowl, so expect two pieces of "salad" on top of your bowl. As with new businesses, I'd say "oh they just need to perfect things" but this was not the case. 

We came here on date night and it was so off putting that an employee was on break talking about marijuana the whole time. The entire time. We were in here almost 30 minutes and the topic never changed. I know I'm probably being picky, but a manager was seated at the next table over and didn't tell him to stop talking about his hobby at work.

I really wanted to love this place. I wanted to experience some innovative and fresh Asian fusion... I was disappointed.

The most positive thing I can start with is the customer service and the patience and smiles that came from the staff. The crew here is definitely well trained and knowledgeable about the menu and options. The manager even swapped my son's chicken when he found it to be too bitter from the charring.

My son really enjoyed the meatballs, which I found to be the second best thing about ShopHouse.

Aside from that, the food was average to good at best. I found it lacking in flavors except for the really strong bitterness of the charred beans and corn.

My take is that Chipotle wowed is with its simplicity, freshness, and familiar flavors. ShopHouse broke from this concept by taking a risk with strong (traditional?) burnt flavors and departing from the conservative palettes of its loyal Chipotle demographic.

I want ShopHouse to do well, but I will likely wait for some menu updates before returning. I wish the marketing lived up to my expectations.

The food was better than I expected. I came here during lunch hours and even though it was very busy, the staff was incredibly friendly.  I overheard the manager answer a few questions to the people in front of me and he seemed very patient as he explained the process of how to order and what he recommended to get. A+ for customer service!

I actually really enjoyed my food. I got the chicken bowl with brown rice, green beans,papaya salad,and red curry sauce. The green bean was charred and although I love the grilled taste, I dont think it's very good for the body to get it frequently (carinogens and all). The papaya salad was a great addition to my bowl and I would definitely get it again. The red curry sauce was incredibly spicy, just FYI for people who can't handle it. I also bought a mango coconut rice parfait which i really enjoyed as a snack later in the day. 

The only thing I wish they would change is being more generous with the toppings. I guess I'm spoiled from Chipotle since they seem to put a good amount of toppings to give me my money's worth. Shophouse seemed to be a little more stingy. I don't like how we are limited to only one type of vegetable. They don't seem to give that much in the first place, so being able to put more than 1 type of veggie would be preferred. 

All in all, I would come back to try a different combination of the foods.

Not bad. It's owned by Chipotle', so the setup of food choosing is similar. 
It's basically a Vietnamese/Tai version of Chipotle. 
When we arrived, the friendly fellow behind the counter asked if this is our first time here. When we said it was, he explained how everything works in a very hospitable kind of way. 
When I asked if they have MSG in any of the food or sauces, he double-checked with the manager, a kind and knowing young woman, who assured me that they don't and insisted that their food is the same quality as their flagship restaurant. 

Pros:
+very chipotle-like
+owned by Chipotle, so the food's the same quality (I suppose this could also be a con)
+good amounts of parking 
+good for lunch
+very friendly staff
+sells beer, if you want it

Cons:
- doesn't sell juice
-a little loud
- We actually got bored of it half way through - you know, when you're no longer eating it because you're enjoying it, but because it's in front of you and you're still hungry. 
-1 bottled water costs $2.00

When I heard that Chipotle was creating an "asian fusion" brainchild, I was super excited to try this. And I was not disappointed. The setup is similar to Chipotle (as to be expected) and there are many choices for rice/noodles, protein, veggies, and other toppings. I ended up going with the ShopHouse bowl with a little tofu on the side. The bowl was amazing! A perfect bend of flavors topped with cilantro. I had a Jasmine tea ginger ale which was totally worth it. Additionally, I tried the rice pudding/mango dessert. For $1.90, it's worth the pocket change. 

Bonus points for having a vertical and horizontal (more upside down "L" shaped) glass in front of the line. Because it's a total pet peeve of mine when people peer over the glass and point or hang their DNA over the food on the line. So bonus points for having some protection from that.

I think they should have a tofu option that is truly vegetarian (it is soaked in fish sauce and therefore not an option for non-meateaters). Otherwise, no complaints!

I wish this place was closer to me, because I would definitely go more often! Please put a location in Naperville or Aurora!

This was a spontaneous stop as we were driving down meacham looking for a dinner spot. We like trying new things, so figured it was worth a go.
Upon walking in we were greeted by a very young, friendly staff, rattling off their schpeel about being a part of Chipotle, same process just with Thai cuisine. That was a bit of a hit on my expectations as I'm not a huge Chipotle fan, but I'll try anything once. 
Choice of carb, protein, condiments, and sauce. So here's the nitty gritty;

The food
Pros:
Build your meal per your preferences. Brown rice was cooked pretty nicely. They let you try if you have any questions before you decide.

Cons:
Medium to lower quality food. Very similar to Chipotle, with unbalanced flavors, over cooked veg and a very mass produced flavor (that's the best way to put it). I definitely recommend the rice, as the noodles were both an odd texture and had an artificial taste. As a vegetarian I can't speak for the meat, but I tried the tofu prior to ordering and it was over cooked, tasteless and chewy, so double veg was where it was at. For double veg. though, it definitely was not much at all, and as stated before they were a bit overcooked and kind of bland. 
 Vegetarians BEWARE, ask about fish sauce in the dishes as you assemble.  It was only after my bowl had been completed and rung up that we were informed that at least two or three things in my bowl had fish sauce it...

The service:
Very friendly kids, a little unprofessional and uninformed, but well intentioned and helpfully. We were even approached by an extremely sweet employee to check in on our experience and given logo coupons for our next visit.

Overall an okay fast casual option, might have to give it a bit of time as they are fairly new and need to find their Grove. Personally probably won't be back on a regular basis, as I'm not a fan of spicy, but I'll probably give it another try if only to use that bogo coupon hah.

ShopHouse is a place that I wish was closer to my house because it offers food that is quick, healthy and delivers solid flavor and quality combined with a fun experience. 

Essentially ShopHouse is kind of carryout, quick serve, Vietnamese restaurant built on the Chipotle approach to Mexican cooking. For me, ShopHouse delivered nicely. 

I had the steak Laab and spiced it up with the spicy green beans, green curry sauce and some hot peppers. The combo worked great with no particular food drowning out the rest. 

The mango coconut pudding thing for dessert was a nice way to finish. The mixture of the fruits works great and the way it's served in a little shot glass is perfect too in terms of portion and presentation. 

Sadly, Schaumburg is a little out of the way for me. But if I am up this way again and feeling Vietnamese food, I'd definitely visit ShopHouse again.

If you're a lover of Chipotle - you'll probably like this place as well. It's got that fast-casual eating experience - where you feel like you're eating quality meals with out compromises.

I got a white rice bowl with half meatballs, and half chicken, topped with the peanut sauce, and pretty much said yes to all of the other ingredients they asked if I wanted. Probably should have dialed down what I added, as some of the things I added were a little too spicy for my liking. Chicken I noticed was way too finely diced - didn't really appreciate that; however, the meatballs were pretty good. 

I also tried the cold spring roll thing - ehh, i wouldnt bother on this item.

Grrrrr 3 stars for the American version of "Asian" food. Well what can I expect from the makers of American burritos??? A star for location, another one for value, and meh throw in another star for their chicken 

Don't get me wrong, I love Chipotle but a very American gourmet southeast Asian dish is just not for me I guess. I don't get the meatball option. Sounds like a ball of unused meats fused together. It's more of like an amalgam of confused meat. IMO, the meatballs don't belong in this equation. 

Anywho, the Chipotle style of make your own meal/bowl is so pass√© and unoriginal. Especially when you get charged for everything "extra" unlike their counterpart where you can load up a bowl to make a 5 pound meal until you can't even make the tortillas meet on your burrito or can't close the bowl because it is whopping with all the extras you've managed to cram in. Fat girl problems! 

I will not be back. Glad I tried it though!

Wow! What a great concept! Owned by Chipotle, ShopHouse brings an Asian flair into the "food fast" concept. You can try their House Favorites, or build your own bowl.

This was my first visit, so I went with the Thai Chicken Peanut Bowl. It certainly has some heat to it, but it was very tasty! The peanut sauce as not as sweet as a typical peanut sauce, but mixed well with the brown rice, corns, carrots, cilantro, peanuts and spicy chicken! I got some green beans mixed in too.

Can't wait to come back and try a different concoction!

This may work for areas that don't have a lot of Asian food, but Schaumburg and the surrounding cities have quite a lot of options, especially for good Thai food.  This would be counted among the worst of them, both for lack of taste and lack of options.  Not a single one of the ingredients (4-5 each of meats, sauces, veggies) interested me. What I got was a totally average bowl of what might be compared to leftovers.  They didn't even have real chicken, just some chicken meatballs, which were admittedly the best thing about the meal.  But the rice, the curry, the corn, the veggies, all of it was just so... meh.

And to add insult to injury, it cost $8 per bowl.  I could get double the portions of better food for that price at the worst of the local Thai takeout restaurants.

Huge disappointment, will not give it another chance when there are so many better options.

I was soooooo excited for ShopHouse's opening - anxiously awaiting it's arrival and stalking the updates for several months. I went on opening day when they were giving free bowls...but sadly the line was down the block and I went somewhere else. I finally got back there yesterday to give them a go.

I'm not feeling it. I tried. I wanted to. I really wanted to. But I just didn't find it delicious. I found most of the ingredients to be really random and don't mesh together quite well. I went with a pretty basic combination and thought I couldn't go wrong with various foods I liked - well, I wasn't right. While it was edible, I just didn't find it fantastic.

Jasmine Rice - The rice was cooked perfectly and the portion was generous. No complaints with my bowl base.
Pork & Chicken Meatballs - Everyone loves their meatballs! I liked them just fine but didn't find them amazing. They have 'fresh herbs' in them but silly me didn't think twice about that bit of them. Part of the fresh herbs is cilantro. I know cilantro is a huge part of Southeast Asian food...but it's one food that absolutely grosses me out. So thanks to that gross little green herb, I didn't enjoy the meatballs much.
